content.title: Truth Values Concept 1
content.statement: The set of truth values is denoted as $\mathcal{V} = \{T, F\}$ (or $\{1, 0\}$), representing the fundamental semantic units in classical logic.

content.title: Connectives Concept 2
content.statement: A logical connective of arity $n$ is a function $f: \{T, F\}^n \to \{T, F\}$. Standard connectives include negation ($\neg$), conjunction ($\land$), disjunction ($\lor$), and implication ($\to$).

content.title: Valuations Concept 3
content.statement: A valuation $v$ is a function $v: \text{Var} \to \{T, F\}$ assigning a truth value to each propositional variable. It extends recursively to all formulas.

content.title: Satisfiability Concept 4
content.statement: A formula $\phi$ is satisfiable if there exists a valuation $v$ such that $v(\phi) = T$ (denoted $v \models \phi$).

content.title: Validity Concept 5
content.statement: A formula $\phi$ is valid (a tautology) if for every valuation $v$, $v(\phi) = T$ (denoted $\models \phi$).

content.title: Tautologies Concept 6
content.statement: A tautology is a formula that is true under every possible valuation. Examples include $P \lor \neg P$.

content.title: Contradictions Concept 7
content.statement: A contradiction is a formula that is false under every possible valuation. Example: $P \land \neg P$.

content.title: Normal Forms Concept 8
content.statement: A normal form is a standard structure for formulas. Common forms include Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF) and Disjunctive Normal Form (DNF).

content.title: CNF Concept 9
content.statement: A formula is in Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF) if it is a conjunction of clauses, where each clause is a disjunction of literals. $\bigwedge_i \bigvee_j l_{ij}$

content.title: DNF Concept 10
content.statement: A formula is in Disjunctive Normal Form (DNF) if it is a disjunction of clauses, where each clause is a conjunction of literals. $\bigvee_i \bigwedge_j l_{ij}$

content.title: Inference Rules Concept 11
content.statement: An inference rule is a syntactic transformation rule of the form $\frac{\phi_1, \dots, \phi_n}{\psi}$, allowing the derivation of conclusion $\psi$ from premises $\phi_i$.

content.title: Soundness Concept 12
content.statement: Soundness is the property that if a formula $\phi$ is provable ($\\vdash \\phi$), then it is valid ($\\models \\phi$). $\Gamma \\vdash \\phi \\implies \\Gamma \\models \\phi$.

content.title: Completeness Concept 13
content.statement: Completeness is the property that if a formula $\phi$ is valid ($\\models \\phi$), then it is provable ($\\vdash \\phi$). $\Gamma \\models \\phi \\implies \\Gamma \\vdash \\phi$.

content.title: Compactness Concept 14
content.statement: The Compactness Theorem states that a set of formulas $\Gamma$ is satisfiable if and only if every finite subset $\Gamma_0 \subseteq \Gamma$ is satisfiable.

content.title: Boolean Algebra Concept 15
content.statement: A Boolean Algebra is a structure $(B, \land, \lor, \neg, 0, 1)$ satisfying axioms of associativity, commutativity, distributivity, identity, and complementation.

content.title: Resolution Concept 17
content.statement: Resolution is an inference rule used for automated theorem proving in CNF, defined as: from $(A \lor x)$ and $(B \lor \neg x)$, infer $(A \lor B)$.

content.title: Natural Deduction Concept 18
content.statement: Natural Deduction is a proof system relying on introduction and elimination rules for each connective, mirroring human reasoning patterns.

content.title: Syntax Concept 19
content.statement: Syntax defines the formal grammar of well-formed formulas (WFFs) using an alphabet of symbols and formation rules, independent of meaning.

content.title: Newton's Second Law
content.statement: The force acting on an object is equal to the mass of that object times its acceleration.

content.title: Conservation of Energy
content.statement: The total energy of an isolated system remains constant over time.

content.title: Pythagorean Theorem
content.statement: In a right triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of squares of the other two sides.

content.title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
content.statement: Differentiation and integration are inverse operations.

content.title: Modal Logic K Axiom
content.statement: If necessarily A implies B, then if A is necessary, B is necessary.

content.title: Modus Ponens
content.statement: If A is true and A implies B, then B is true.

content.title: Matrix Multiplication
content.statement: The product of two matrices is computed by summing products of corresponding elements.

content.title: Addition
content.statement: The sum of two numbers is their addition.

content.title: Subtraction
content.statement: The difference between two numbers is their subtraction.

content.title: Multiplication
content.statement: The product of two numbers is their multiplication.

content.title: Division
content.statement: The quotient of two numbers is their division.

content.title: Modal T Axiom (Reflexivity)
content.statement: If p is necessary, then p is true. Valid in reflexive frames.

content.title: Modal 4 Axiom (Transitivity)
content.statement: If p is necessary, then it is necessarily necessary. Valid in transitive frames.

content.title: Modal D Axiom (Serial)
content.statement: If p is necessary, then p is possible. Valid in serial frames.

content.title: Modal 5 Axiom (Euclidean)
content.statement: If p is possible, then it is necessarily possible. Valid in euclidean frames.

content.title: Modal B Axiom (Symmetric)
content.statement: If p is true, then it is necessarily possible. Valid in symmetric frames.

content.title: Modal Duality
content.statement: Possibility and necessity are dual operators.

content.title: Tautology Checker
content.formula: Truth table verification for all variable assignments
content.statement: Determines if a propositional formula is always true (tautology).

content.title: SAT Solver
content.statement: Determines if a propositional formula is satisfiable.

content.title: De Morgan's Laws
content.statement: Laws for negation of conjunctions and disjunctions.

content.title: Distribution Laws
content.statement: Laws for distribution of conjunction and disjunction.

content.title: Double Negation
content.statement: Double negation elimination.

content.title: Implication Equivalence
content.statement: Implication can be expressed as disjunction.

content.title: Contraposition
content.statement: An implication is equivalent to its contrapositive.
